segment.source: Capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Tracelog and Xperf are used to capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile.
segment.target: Tracelog and Xperf are used to capture event trace logs on Windows 10 Mobile.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: To capture trace logs, the device image must be built with the appropriate type and packages.
segment.target: To capture trace logs, the device image must be built with the appropriate type and packages.

segment.source: This is done by modifying the OEMInput file to set the ReleaseType element to Test, and adding TESTINFRASTRUCTURE to the Features element.
segment.target: This is done by modifying the OEMInput file to set the ReleaseType element to Test, and adding TESTINFRASTRUCTURE to the Features element.

segment.source: Step 1: Install the Windows Performance Toolkit
segment.target: Step 1: Install the Windows Performance Toolkit

segment.source: The Windows Performance Toolkit (WPT) is required to process event trace logs with Xperf.
segment.target: The Windows Performance Toolkit (WPT) is required to process event trace logs with Xperf.

segment.source: The WPT is part of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).
segment.target: The WPT is part of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).

segment.source: Step 2: Install and configure TShell
segment.target: Step 2: Install and configure TShell

segment.source: TShell is required to run Tracelog.
segment.target: TShell is required to run Tracelog.

segment.source: Step 3: Verify device is connected
segment.target: Step 3: Verify device is connected

segment.source: Verify the device is connected to TShell by running the command dird in the TShell command window.
segment.target: Verify the device is connected to TShell by running the command dird in the TShell command window.

segment.source: Ensure a directory listing from the device is displayed.
segment.target: Ensure a directory listing from the device is displayed.

segment.source: If an error message is seen, ensure that TShell is configured correctly, and a device command prompt is shown above the regular command prompt in the TShell window similar to the following:
segment.target: If an error message is seen, ensure that TShell is configured correctly, and a device command prompt is shown above the regular command prompt in the TShell window similar to the following:

segment.source: Step 4: Run Tracelog to start event trace logging
segment.target: Step 4: Run Tracelog to start event trace logging

segment.source: Using the TShell command window, run Tracelog with desired parameters to start event trace logging.
segment.target: Using the TShell command window, run Tracelog with desired parameters to start event trace logging.

segment.source: Two basic examples are below.
segment.target: Two basic examples are below.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: On Windows 10 Mobile, Tracelog must place its logs within the C:data directory due to partition size restrictions.
segment.target: On Windows 10 Mobile, Tracelog must place its logs within the C:data directory due to partition size restrictions.

segment.source: Be sure to use the -f flag to configure Tracelog to use C:data.
segment.target: Be sure to use the -f flag to configure Tracelog to use C:data.

segment.source: For detailed Tracelog command line syntax, see Tracelog Command Syntax.
segment.target: For detailed Tracelog command line syntax, see Tracelog Command Syntax.

segment.source: For additional examples, see Tracelog Examples.
segment.target: For additional examples, see Tracelog Examples.

segment.source: Example 1
segment.target: Example 1

segment.source: The following command starts a session that enables tracing of process and thread create/deletes, kernel and user mode image load/unload events, DPC events, context switches, and CPU sample profiles.
segment.target: The following command starts a session that enables tracing of process and thread create/deletes, kernel and user mode image load/unload events, DPC events, context switches, and CPU sample profiles.

segment.source: Example 2
segment.target: Example 2

segment.source: The following commands start a new session named "MyPowerTrace" and enable the Microsoft-Windows-Kernel-Power provider.
segment.target: The following commands start a new session named "MyPowerTrace" and enable the Microsoft-Windows-Kernel-Power provider.

segment.source: Step 5: Run scenarios or tests
segment.target: Step 5: Run scenarios or tests

segment.source: Event trace logging is now enabled.
segment.target: Event trace logging is now enabled.

segment.source: Run the scenarios or tests you want to analyze.
segment.target: Run the scenarios or tests you want to analyze.

segment.source: Step 6: Run Tracelog to flush the buffers and stop event trace logging
segment.target: Step 6: Run Tracelog to flush the buffers and stop event trace logging

segment.source: After the scenarios or tests are complete, use Tracelog to flush the buffers and stop event trace logging.
segment.target: After the scenarios or tests are complete, use Tracelog to flush the buffers and stop event trace logging.

segment.source: Example 1
segment.target: Example 1

segment.source: The following commands flush and stop the "MyTrace" session.
segment.target: The following commands flush and stop the "MyTrace" session.

segment.source: Example 2
segment.target: Example 2

segment.source: The following commands flush and stop the "MyPowerTrace" session.
segment.target: The following commands flush and stop the "MyPowerTrace" session.

segment.source: Step 7: Run Xperf on the device
segment.target: Step 7: Run Xperf on the device

segment.source: Run Xperf on the device to process the log.
segment.target: Run Xperf on the device to process the log.

segment.source: Example 1
segment.target: Example 1

segment.source: Example 2
segment.target: Example 2

segment.source: Step 8: Copy trace log from device
segment.target: Step 8: Copy trace log from device

segment.source: Copy the merged trace log from the phone by using the getd command in the TShell command window.
segment.target: Copy the merged trace log from the phone by using the getd command in the TShell command window.

segment.source: Example 1
segment.target: Example 1

segment.source: Example 2
segment.target: Example 2

segment.source: You can also rename the file at copy time.
segment.target: You can also rename the file at copy time.

segment.source: Step 9: Run Xperf on the desktop PC
segment.target: Step 9: Run Xperf on the desktop PC

segment.source: Run Xperf on the desktop PC for additional processing.
segment.target: Run Xperf on the desktop PC for additional processing.

segment.source: On 32-bit operating systems, Xperf is installed in C:Program FilesWindows Kits10Windows Performance Toolkit.
segment.target: On 32-bit operating systems, Xperf is installed in C:Program FilesWindows Kits10Windows Performance Toolkit.

segment.source: On 64-bit operating systems, it is installed in C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Windows Performance Toolkit.
segment.target: On 64-bit operating systems, it is installed in C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Windows Performance Toolkit.
